examples: The party's off because the hostess is sick.
Your feet will feel better once those tight boots are off .
The drink spilled out of the bottle because the top was off .

definitions.definition: Denoting something faulty, unsatisfactory, objectionable etc.

subdefinitions.definition: Not correct; not properly formed; not logical, harmonious, etc.
Less than normal, in temperament or in result.
Designating a time when one is not performing to the best of one's abilities.
labels: in phrases such as ' off day '
subdefinitions.label_groups: in phrases such as ' off day '

examples: Our family used to be well off ; now we're very badly off .
How are you off for milk? Shall I get you some more from the shop?
definitions.label_groups: in phrases such as 'well off', 'poorly off', etc., and in 'how?' questions

examples: And they're off ! Whatsmyname takes an early lead, with Remember The Mane behind by a nose.
He took me down the corridor and into an off room.
the off horse or ox in a team, in distinction from the nigh or near horse

definitions.definition: Temporarily not attending a usual place, such as work or school, especially owing to illness or holiday.
examples: John's off today. He's back on Wednesday.

definitions.definition: Designating a time when one is not strictly attentive to business or affairs, or is absent from a post, and, hence, a time when affairs are not urgent.
examples: He took an off day for fishing.  an off year in politics; the off season

definitions.definition: Presently unavailable . ( of a dish on a menu )
examples: I'll have the chicken please. — Sorry, chicken's off today.

definitions.definition: On the side furthest from the kerb (the right-hand side if one drives on the left).
examples: The off front wheel came loose.
definitions.label_groups: British , in relation to a vehicle

definitions.definition: In, or towards the half of the field away from the batsman 's legs ; the right side for a right-handed batsman.

secondary_definitions: Denoting something faulty, unsatisfactory, objectionable etc.
( in phrases such as 'well off', 'poorly off', etc., and in 'how?' questions ) Circumstanced .
Temporarily not attending a usual place, such as work or school, especially owing to illness or holiday.
Designating a time when one is not strictly attentive to business or affairs, or is absent from a post, and, hence, a time when affairs are not urgent.
( predicative only ) Presently unavailable . ( of a dish on a menu )
( British , in relation to a vehicle ) On the side furthest from the kerb (the right-hand side if one drives on the left).
( cricket ) In, or towards the half of the field away from the batsman 's legs ; the right side for a right-handed batsman.
